conclusion: Determine the height \( h_a \) from which the ball \( a \) is released so that it can just fly out from point \( D \).
The ball slides down the inclined rail \( PA \) under the influence of gravity.
The potential energy at height \( h_a \) is converted into kinetic energy at point \( A \).
The potential energy at height \( h_a \) is \( mgh_a \).
The kinetic energy at point \( A \) is \( \frac{1}{2}mv_A^2 \), where \( v_A \) is the velocity at point \( A \).
The ball slides on the horizontal rail \( AB \) and then enters the semicircular track \( BCD \).
The velocity at point \( A \) is \( v_A = \sqrt{2gh_a} \).
The velocity at point \( B \) is the same as the velocity at point \( A \) because there is no friction on the horizontal rail.
The ball must just fly out from point \( D \), which means the normal force at point \( D \) is zero.
This is the condition for the ball to be in circular motion with the required centripetal force provided by the electric force.
The centripetal force required is \( \frac{mv_D^2}{R} \), and the electric force is \( qE \).
For the ball to just fly out, the normal force at point \( D \) is zero: \( \frac{mv_D^2}{R} = qE \).
The ball moves from point \( B \) to point \( D \) under the influence of gravity and the electric field.
The electric field provides a horizontal force, but the vertical component of the velocity remains the same.
The horizontal component of the velocity decreases due to the electric field.
The horizontal component of the velocity at point \( B \) is \( v_{Ax} = v_A \cos \theta \) and the vertical component is \( v_{Ay} = v_A \sin \theta \).
